titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Records of the Peace Corps Training Program RISM.RG.6
titlestmt.author: Emilyn L. Brown, April 2007 and edited by Nancy Cricco in March 2009. Inventory edited by Margaret Fraser and Samantha Gibson.

editionstmt.p: This version was derived from Guide to Records-Jamaic-PC.doc

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-06-27 17:45:08 -0400.

change.item: Updated by Lyric Evans-Hunter to reflect the digitization of audiovisual materials.

did.unittitle: Records of the Jamaica Peace Corps Training Program
did.abstract: In 1961 the Research Institute for the Study of Man (RISM) was contracted to train volunteers for the United States Peace Corps. Transferred to the Caribbean, the volunteers assisted the Jamaican government by training workers in librarianship, industrial arts, nursing and vocational education. The collection, which reflects the early years of the Peace Corps, and RISM's specialized knowledge of the Caribbean, includes correspondence, financial records, teaching papers, training guides, clippings, photographs, print material, reports, cassette tapes, and compact discs.
did.physloc: Materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please request materials at least two business days prior to your research visit to coordinate access.

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: The records of the Peace Corps Training Program were generated by Dr. Vera D. Rubin (1911 - 1985), Director of the Research Institute for The Study of Man (RISM) and her staff in fulfillment of a contract with The U.S. Peace Corps.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The collection was processed by Emilyn L. Brown between Mar - Apr 2007

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research with the exception of part or all of Series III, IV, V, and IX, which are restricted.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Permission to publish materials must be obtained in writing from the: >New York University Archives; Elmer Holmes Bobst Library, 70 Washington Square South, New York, NY 10012. Phone: (212) 998-2646; Fax: (212) 995-4225; E-mail:university-archives@nyu.edu

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: On March 1, 1961, President John F. Kennedy established the U.S. Peace Corps to promote international peace efforts through volunteer workers. Based on its specialization in Caribbean research, the Research Institute for the Study of Man (RISM) was selected to train Peace Corps volunteers to assist and support the vocational adult education programs sponsored by the government in Jamaica, West Indies.

The initial phase of the training program was conducted between April 2 - May 31, 1962 with Peace Corps volunteers housed at the International House situated on the Columbia University campus. Dr. Vera Rubin served as a consultant for the program, which was co-directed by Drs. Lambros Comitas and Robert Stigler. Course work included Caribbean (area) studies, American studies and world affairs, technical and agricultural training, commerce, industrial arts and health care. Noted anthropologists Sidney Mintz, David Lowenthal, M.G. Smith and others gave lectures. Many individuals involved in public service provided lectures for the American Affairs unit, notably Dean Acheson, U.S. Secretary of State from 1949 - 1953, Zbigniew K. Brzezinski, and Adlai E. Stevenson.

The Program's field trips and extra-curricular activities included a visit to Hyde Park, New York, where volunteers spoke with Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt, attending the birthday party of President John F. Kennedy at Madison Square Garden in New York City and visits to the Library of Congress in Washington, D.C.

During the second phase of the training program, volunteers received additional instruction and orientation to the region at the University College of the West Indies (UCWI) at Mona, Jamaica, W.I. Approximately 30 Peace Corps volunteers were assigned to diverse institutions, including youth camps at Chestervald and Cobbla, Regional Trade Training Centers, Teacher Training Colleges that included the Mico Training College for Teachers, the Shortwood Training College for Women Teachers, and at Frome Senior High Schools, Holmwood Technical School in Manchester, Vere Technical School in Clarendon and technical institutes in Port Antonio and Montego Bay. Their work responsibilities included teaching industrial arts, vocational skills, commercial bookeeping, chemistry, biology and physics. Other volunteers worked as nurse-educators, participated in agricultural projects or assisted the Jamaican Library Service, and the University College of the West Indies with cataloguing and classification.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The records of the Jamaica Peace Corps Training Program document the activities of the U.S. Peace Corps, and the Research Institute for the Study of Man (RISM) from the 1960s through the 1980s. The bulk of the collection, which consists of 21 boxes and approximately 12 linear feet, documents the actual training program, which was conducted between April - May 1962. The materials generated during the course of the Program are mainly textual in nature comprising correspondence between the U.S. Peace Corps, staff and faculty members, and Dr. Vera Rubin. Other textual documents include program guides, which outline the goals and objectives of setting up a training program and includes RISM's own training proposal. Syllabai and teaching papers, publications, clippings, maps, reports and print materials associated with the Program's graduation ceremony are also included.

Other formats in the collection are individual and group photographs of the Peace Corps Volunteers, and tickets from the birthday celebrtion organized for John F. Kennedy at Madison Square Garden. Audiovisual materials include a film reel of the volunteer's visit to Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt, audiocassettes and reel-to-reel tapes of the Jamaican Language Guide by Mrs. Beryl Bailey, class lectures, and the Graduation ceremony. Note: Several series pertaining to the Peace Corps volnteers are restricted due to the sensitive nature of the materials and privacy of individuals. These series are as follows: Series III. Volunteer Registration Records, Series IV. Health Services, Series V. Volunteer Evaluation, and Series IX. Volunteer Files.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The papers of the Jamaica Peace Corps. Project are arranged as # series, and some further arranged as subseries. The contents of each series or subseries is arranged chronologically with the exception of Series V, Volunteer Records, which is arranged alphabetically.
The files are grouped into 19 series:

list.head: Series
list.item: VIII. Field Trips and Extra-Curricular Activities

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Material
separatedmaterial.p: There is no information about materials that are associated by provenance to the described materials that have been physically separated or removed.

Research Institute for the Study of Man

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 1.0 linear feet (2 boxes) arranged chronologically. The correspondence series, which contains incoming and outgoing letters, documents the early relationship between the U.S. Peace Corps and the Research Institute for the Study of Man (RISM). The bulk of material was generated between March - April of 1962, and relates specifically to the training curriculum for Peace Corps Volunteers (PCV). Notable correspondents include Seargent Shriver, director of the Peace Corps, the Honorable Norman W. Manley, Beryl Bailey, H.D. Huggins and other faculty members of the University College of the West Indies (UCWI). Letters establishing potential placement, recruitment of training personnel and forms letters to new volunteers are also included.

did.unittitle: Peace Corps Volunteer lists, welcome letters
Correspondence, list of telegrams and cables
Series II. Peace Corps Program Development

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 1.25 linear feet (2.5 boxes) arranged chronologically. This series contains national and international Peace Corps programs that provide an overview of the goals and principles of the agency. Other materials include the Peace Corps Fact Book, instructional handbooks, syllabi, training reports, testing requirements, project descriptions, and related correspondence and memorandum, which were used in the development of RISM's training program (see Series VI).

Series III. Volunteer Registration Records [Some material restricted]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: .5 linear feet (1 box), arranged chronologically. This series documents the registration process and includes correspondence, questionnaires, volunteer lists, Peace Corps brochures, instructions, forms, and print material from International House where volunteers resided during their training. Because of the sensitive nature of material that appears on the registration forms, folders 13 and 14 are restricted.

did.unittitle: Instructions for Completing Form PC-52 Notice of Volunteers Registered for Training
Annual Report, forms for International House, notes
Project Invitation Summary Sheets, correspondence with Peace Corps questionnaire
The Peace Corps FactBook, forms, instructions
Jamaica Instructions for Reporting to the Peace Corps Reception Center, International House, New York
U.S. Civil Service Commission Fingerprint Charts, volunteer identification card numbers
International House brochures, room assignments, instructions, memorandum, notes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: approximately .5 linear feet (1 box), arranged chronologically. The papers in this series, which relate to the health and well being of Peace Corps volunteers, include brochures, medical budgets, correspondence, medical reports and summaries. Because of the sensitive nature of the material, the entire series is restricted.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: .5 liner feet (1 box), arranged chronologically. This series mainly consists of personal interviews, psychiatric evaluations, and self-evaluation forms for volunteers. Correspondence, articles, reports, statistical summary cards and notes are also included. Because of the sensitive nature of the papers, the entire series is restricted.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: .5 linear feet (1 box), arranged chronologically. The papers in this series document the organization and day-to-day operations of the Jamaica Peace Corps Training Program. Included are program proposals, curriculum vitae for staff and faculty, program schedules, syllabi, correspondence, general reading lists, and notes (see Series VII. Teaching Papers for specific subject curriculum).

did.unittitle: Proposal for a Peace Corps Training Program, Contract Article I - Definitions, Article II - General Scope of the Program, draft chart, notes
Proposal for a Peace Corps Training Program [original typescript]
List of Program staff and faculty
Curriculum vitae for staff and faculty, A - B
Curriculum vitae for staff and faculty, C
Curriculum vitae for staff and faculty, D - L
Curriculum vitae for staff and faculty, O - S
Correspondence, curriculum vitae for staff and faculty U - Z, staff and faculty telephone address list, notes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Two linear feet (4 boxes), arranged chronologically. This series highlights the academic and technical training taught in the program. These training materials have been organized as five subseries: Subseries A. Peace Corps Orientation, Program Syllabi, and Area Studies, on the history, geography and culture of Jamaica, W.I., including the original typescript, A Language Guide toJamaica, written by Beryl Bailey. Note: Recorded versions of this guide can be found in Series XIV, Audio-visual Materials. The papers in Subseries B. Technical Studies, relate to studies in the industrial arts, vocational education, biological science, agriculture, library science, nursing, plumbing, auto mechanics and other trades. Subseries C. American Studies and World Affairs focused on communism and other newsworthy events during the 1960s. The papers in Subseries D. Health Training, mainly relate to public health education. Subseries E. Physical Education relates to physical fitness soccer, cricket and other sports activities.

Series VIII. Field Trips and Special Events

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 8 folders, arranged chronologically. This series documents the various field trips and extra-curricular activities organized on behalf of the Peace Corps volunteers. Highlights of this series include correspondence between Dr. Rubin and Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt regarding a visit to Hyde Park, letters to Adelai Stevenson, at the United Nations, and the volunteers visit to highly publicized birthday rally held for President John F. Kennedy at Madison Square Garden in New York City. Volunteers also visited major libraries, the New Jersey Department of Labor and Agriculture, and toured Washington, D.C.

did.unittitle: Correspondence related to Hyde Park visit
Correspondence, agenda for Washington, D.C. tour
Correspondence, agenda for visit to N.J. Dept. of Labor and Agriculture, notes
Correspondence Annual Dance, Caribbean Federation for Mental Health
Correspondence and agenda for various library visits
Correspondence, ticket for Madison Square Birthday Rally held for President John F. Kennedy
Agenda, brochure on West Indian dance, notes
Directions to Manhattan sites, visitors guide, Columbia University Student Handbook, miscellaneous papers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 1.0 linear feet (2 boxes) arranged alphabetically. This is a restricted series that contains individual volunteer files consisting of biographical data, self-evaluation inventories, confidential reports, test booklets, personal interviews, profile and case summaries, test scores, assessment summaries, and essays. There are also volunteer evaluations of the Peace Corps Training Program.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Approximately .75 linear feet (1 box), arranged chronologically. This series documents volunteer placement by region and area of study, selective service status where applicable, and other items effecting their assignments. Also included are numerous forms issued by the Peace Corps, correspondence, memorandum, passport and visa applications and instructions, suggestions for clothing and miscellaneous papers.

did.unittitle: Report of Final Selection Board forms, volunteer placement lists by region and area of study
Correspondence Office of Selection, volunteer placement lists by region; volunteer lists
Memorandum Concerning [Military] Selective Service and Reserve Obligations

Correspondence, clothing suggestions for Jamaica, W.I.
Clothing suggestions for Peace Corp Projects in Brazil and El Salvador
Instructions, Notice of Termination of Volunteer in Training forms, notes
Instructions and Application to Withdraw Termination Payments, notes
Memorandum, forms and correspondence concerning to departure and home leave

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 1 vol., contents arranged alphabetically by volunteer's last name. The binder contains original and Xeroxed group photos (8 x 10). Two photographs (5 x 7) of each volunteer are consecutively numbered and lettered "a" and "b." The binder also contains a photograph of Herbert L. Wright, Youth Secretary of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. Wright was one of several lecturers for the Area Studies component of the Peace Corps Training Program. Invoices, notes and miscellaneous papers related to the photographs are also included.

did.unittitle: Peace Corps Group Photograph taken by Alex Aster [original]
Wright, Herbert L., Youth Secretary, NAACP [See box 11, folder 45

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 6 folders, arranged chronologically. The papers in this series were created to promote the Peace Corps Training Program. Included are press releases, correspondence announcements, media interviews and broadcasts. See also Series XIV. Audiovisual Materials.

did.unittitle: Draft copy, press release announcement of Jamaica Peace Corps Training Program
Correspondence, notes regarding volunteer radio and television interviews

List of radio and television and coverage of the program in New York, draft statement describing press coverage in the Jamaica Daily Gleaner and the Peace Corps Training graduation ceremonies described in the New York Times
Announcement of Peace Corps Training Program graduation broadcast on The Listener's Digest, WRUL

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Approximately 2.0 linear feet (2 boxes), contents arranged chronologically. This series is comprised of newspaper clippings. Although some clippings relate to the Peace Corps Program and its volunteers, other clippings describe issues in the Caribbean, the U.S. Civil Rights movement, and communism, some of which were most likely used in teaching. Additional clippings are included under Series XIV. Oversized Materials

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 1.0 linear feet (1 oversized box). This series contains oversized maps and illustrations, used to support the coursework and technical training taught in the Peace Corps Training Program, particularly area studies, geography and agricultural skills. Some illustrations relate to the volunteers' specific assignments.

did.unittitle: British Caribbean Colonies, color print map by Leo Vernon, distributed by British Information Services
Two hand drawn maps of Cousins Cove, Pedro Pen and surrounding area
Details of regional placement based on map; two survey maps of Jamaica, W.I.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: (1 record carton). This series consists of reel-to-reel audio and visual recordings of the Jamaica Peace Corps training activities. The tapes includes lectures, the graduation ceremony, volunteer interviews, and a visit with Mrs. Franklin Roosevelt at Hyde Park, New York. Several recordings in this series, which were transferred to CD/DVD format, have been appended to the collection.

Series XVI. Peace Corps Graduation Ceremony

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: .5 linear feet (1 box), arranged chronologically. This series documents the planning activities leading up to the graduation ceremony held for Peace Corps Volunteers. The papers include correspondence, invitations, programs, diplomas and related material.

did.unittitle: Correspondence, includes telegram from Robert Sargent Shriver, Jr.
International House Booking Charge Sheets, stage and seating diagram, notes
Diplomas [void copies not used -- inscribed with volunteer names]
Diplomas [void copies not used -- inscribed with volunteer names]
Series XVII. Peace Corps Volunteer Publications

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: .5 linear feet (1 box), arranged chronologically. This series contains newsletters organized by or published for Peace Corps volunteers. The newsletters provide details of various Peace Corps projects, including the activities of graduates from the Jamaica Peace Corps Training Program.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: .5 linear feet (1 box), arranged chronologically. This series contains correspondence, draft outlines, grading forms and reports submitted by Program faculty and medical consultants. These reports were incorporated in the final Peace Corps report, also included.
